Speaker: construction worker
Dialogue: Your column should be so funny.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: Okay, I was also thinking I might write about...

Speaker: lady
Dialogue: I'm sorry, I don't know any people like that.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: Fisher?  Come on -- I know you're sitting there laughing at me.  Pick up. I want to run an idea past you.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: When your t-shirts stop shrinking.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: I see photos of a lot of dead writers on these walls.  Got any living ones? I have a story to tell that could win one of them a Pulitzer.  Picture this, if you will.  A small town in Maryland, a sleepy little village, within that a hardware store...

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: So what's in store for us in tomorrow's column?

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: I don't know yet.  I'm kind of a last- minute man.  Ideas don't flow until an hour or two before deadline.

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: This is very interesting.  You get your ideas for your column from life.  You start up a conversation with a woman in a bar, attack her choice of reading material, try and get a rise out of her while you contemplate whether or not she's worth hitting on.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: No, I can't hit on you until I get an idea.

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: That's flattering.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: No, you don't understand.

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: I think I do understand.  So my not responding to your baiting me will inspire one of those potential bitter diatribes you love to write about women and all the things we do to drive men crazy?

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: I don't write bitter diatribes about women... very often.

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: Only when the ideas aren't flowing, huh?  Well, it was very nice to meet you, one-minute man.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: And it's the quality that counts.

Speaker: bartender
Dialogue: You know, for a good looking man, you strike out a lot.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: I've seen much worse.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: Excuse me?

Speaker: man
Dialogue: The brush-off.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: Not as private as I thought.

Speaker: bartender
Dialogue: Writing or wiping?

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: Give me a pen.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Ah, come on.  They deserve it.  They love you, they hate you, they're hot, they're cold, they're high, they're low...

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: ... They're up, they're down.  It's really fun making this list with you, but I've got a column to go write.

Speaker: bartender
Dialogue: Ike.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: But you don't have a really superb idea! Well, there's a girl from my hometown you could write about.

Speaker: bartender
Dialogue: Excuse me, we don't need any new ideas.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: She likes to dump grooms right at the altar.  They call her "The Runaway Bride".

Speaker: man
Dialogue: She performed the travesty seven or eight times.  Right at the altar she turns around and runs like hell. Bolts.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: I give up.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: She has the next victim all lined up. She's twirling another body on the spit.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Imagine if you will, a small town in Maryland...

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: "Today is a day of profound introspection, I have been accused of using this column to direct bitter diatribes at the opposite sex!  This uncomfortable accusation has plunged me into at least fifteen minutes of serious reflection, from which I have emerged with the conclusion that, yes -- I traffic in female stereotypes."

Speaker: fisher
Dialogue: "But how can one blame me when every time I step out my front door I meet fresh proof that the female archetypes are alive and well?  Te mother, the virgin, the whore, the crone; they're elbowing you in the subway, stealing your cabs, and overwhelming you with perfume in elevators."

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: "But perhaps, in fairness to the fairer sex, I do need to broaden my horizon and add some new goddesses to the pantheon: I would like to nominate for deity..."

Speaker: fisher
Dialogue: "... The cheerleader, the coed, and the man-eater, the last of which concerns me most today."

Speaker: man
Dialogue: "To be fair, the man-eater isn't exactly new.  In Ancient Greece, this fearsome female was known as Erinys, the devouring death goddess.  In India, she is Kali, who likes to devour her boyfriend Shiva's entrails while her yoni devour his -- dot dot dot, never mind.  In Indonesia, the bloody-jawed man-eater is called Ragma..."

Speaker: bartender
Dialogue: You noticed these are all countries without cable.  ".... AKA, the Runaway Bride."

Speaker: peggy
Dialogue: "What is unusual about Miss Carpenter is that she likes to dress her men up as grooms before she devours them.  She has already disemboweled six in a row by leaving them at the altar."... I can't ready anymore.

Speaker: peggy
Dialogue: No, you tell her.

Speaker: peggy
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: peggy
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Here we go!  One antique hot water handle with the "HOT" still on it, guaranteed to fit any American Standard cast iron tub with a four-inch center made between 1924 and 1938.  In other words, I think you're out of the doghouse with Mrs. Paxton.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Alright, Mr. Paxton, I'll put it on your account.

Speaker: earl
Dialogue: Maggie.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: You don't need an air conditioner, Earl, you just need an attic fan -- There's more in the back.

Speaker: peggy
Dialogue: So -- Mag -- you've seen this, huh?

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Yes, I've seen it.  And I have to say it's the rudest and most offensive... joke anybody's ever played on me!

Speaker: peggy
Dialogue: Uh, Maggie, you told us to bachelorette jokes, so we didn't...

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Um, you know, now would be a good moment to tell me this is fake.  Okay, well... I mean, I can find out... Real newspapers smear.  Phoney papers don't.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: I'll put in a good word for you.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: No, no, don't mention my name in there.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: You can go in now.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: "Anyway, I'm just dropping you big city folk this little note to say that I have thought of a ritual sacrifice that would satisfy my current appetite: Ike Graham's column on a platter.  Yours truly, Maggie Carpenter.  P.S. -- I have inclosed a list of the gross factual misrepresentations in your article.  There are fifteen."

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: Fully.  I like her.  She has wit.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: I left four messages.  You don't return my calls.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: So?  I never returned your calls, even when we were married.  And what's Fisher doing here anyway?

Speaker: fisher
Dialogue: Ellie asked me to come down to offer moral support.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: Since when does Ellie need moral supp--

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: -- It's for you, Ike.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Journalism lesson number one.  If you fabricate your facts, you get fired.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: Lesson number two.  Never work for your former spouse.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: That's not nothing to do with it.  You cooked this story up and you know it.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: I didn't cook up a story.  I had a source.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Someone reliable, I'm sure.  A booze- hound in a bar?

Speaker: fisher
Dialogue: In vino veritas.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: Don't knock drunk guys in bars.  Drunk guys in bars are good.  It means they're not driving.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: No, that's what makes you unemployed.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: I merely write the stuff.  You're the one that serves it up.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Not anymore.  I have to draw the line.  She sent us this list.  Our lawyers say it's actionable.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: I don't know, Ellie -- Firing me is going to be very tough on you.  It's going to be hard to get over.  There will be therapy bills for you.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: I already made an appointment for later today.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: See?  You want custody of my job? ... Why not just consider my wrist slapped and call me when you feel I've served my time?

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: I'm sorry, Ike.  This is permanent.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: She canned him, she canned him...

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Come here, Mag, and try this on.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Listen: "Dear Ms. Carpenter, I apologize to you for this unfortunate matter.  Ike Graham's column will no longer be appearing in this paper. Best of luck in you upcoming marriage!"

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: That-a-girl!  You sacked him.  This is the weight of the pack you're going to have to carry in the Himalayas. Tell me if it's too heavy.

Speaker: fisher
Dialogue: Ike, I really liked the Runaway Bride piece, and since I do freelance stuff for G.Q., I'm in a different position now...

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: What are you trying to say to me, Fish?

Speaker: fisher
Dialogue: Vindication.  How would you like to get some?  A chance to prove that, though your facts weren't entirely straight, your theory was correct.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: The real story on Miss Carpenter.

Speaker: fisher
Dialogue: All the gory details.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: The anatomy of the black widow spider of Maryland.

Speaker: fisher
Dialogue: It wouldn't be a bad way to get you back into writing feature pieces again.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: This is good.  It is a good story, Fish.

Speaker: fisher
Dialogue: If she runs, then it's a cover story. All true.  All accurate.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: Okay, you were right.  I hated my column, but I can do this assignment.

Speaker: fisher
Dialogue: Then you've got it.  If you leave tomorrow for the hinterlands, you'll have plenty of time before her next wedding trot.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: "Paid vindication"  That's what I call justice.

Speaker: fisher
Dialogue: Justice, yes.  Paid, I don't know. They like the idea, but my hands are tied with budget restraints.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: But I'll get my normal fee, right?

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: You want me to do it on spec?!

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: I think I'm in Maryberry.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Cindy, you better 86 Sprout.  He seems to be enjoying the petroleum distillates.

Speaker: cindy
Dialogue: That's it.  Back to obedience school.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Okay -- have a seat... gently, carefully.

Speaker: peggy
Dialogue: You're a goddess!

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: I didn't even need to change this gasket, just put in a little hydraulic fluid.

Speaker: peggy
Dialogue: Stop it.  When you talk like that, I get turned on and it frightens me.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: Hello.  I'm looking for Maggie Carpenter.  There was a sign at the hardware store across the street...

Speaker: peggy
Dialogue: Are you a reporter?

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: peggy
Dialogue: It's been our experience that anyone with some sort of gewgaw on his loafers ends up being another big city reporter wanting to interview Maggie.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: About her upcoming wedding and all.

Speaker: peggy
Dialogue: No, about her getting that asshole from New York fired.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: I am just such a reporter.  And you are?

Speaker: peggy
Dialogue: Peggy Phleming.  Not the ice skater.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: And who are these lovely ladies?

Speaker: cindy
Dialogue: Cindy.  Maggie's unmarried cousin.

Speaker: peggy
Dialogue: And you are?

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: Looking for Maggie.

Speaker: peggy
Dialogue: Yep.  Maggie -- Someone to see you.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Reporter?

Speaker: peggy
Dialogue: Yup!

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: I hope you have a different angle. It's pretty much all been covered.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: Originality is my speciality.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Excellent.

Speaker: peggy
Dialogue: Hold on -- Nobody interviews Maggie in here unless they're getting haircut.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: She's the boss.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: Sorry, no.  I just got one.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: Yes, Mrs. Pressman.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: I know.  Tell me something.  Do you think she's going to make it all the way this time?

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: She swallowed her gun.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: Good fact.  Well, you let me know.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Well, instead of a haircut, how about a wash?  You know, get all that city grit out of it.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: You'll answer my questions?

Speaker: peggy
Dialogue: Great.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Have a seat.  Peggy, why don't you give him the special treatment that strengthens the follicles.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: Getting nervous?

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Nervous?  Not at all!  No.  I've never been more certain in my life.  Except -- I am having all kinds of weird dreams.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: Weird dreams?  You're going to tell me about them?

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: peggy
Dialogue: Let's just put this back here for the aromatherapy.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: In another one...

Speaker: peggy
Dialogue: Hey, Pete, I'll be right with you.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: I'm inside the church.  Everyone I know is there, only they're not really them. They're like Frankenstein monsters, but without the bolts coming out of their necks.  It's all very "Night of the Living Dead".  And here's the creepiest part -- I look down at my dress and it's red.  I mean, I have no idea what it means.  Red's not my color!

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: I think you'd look good in red.

Speaker: peggy
Dialogue: No, she's talking about your hair.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: You're all ready for football season, Mr. Graham.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: Yes, I think I nailed the personality profile of the women of Hale.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: Doc's Pharmacy.  Third and Elm.  Tell him Pete sent you.  Want my hat?

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: No thanks.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: He seems crabby.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: If you're looking for Elm Street, it's that way.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: If you came down here in the pursuit of happiness, you might as well go back. Because you can't make me feel bad.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: I'm not here to make you feel bad.  I'm here for vindication.  In my heart...

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: You have one?

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: I feel I'm right about you.  You got me fired, lady.  You destroyed my reputation and you screwed up my hair. You chew men up, spit them out and loved it.  And I'm down here to satisfy myself on that point.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Did something happen to make you care about reality?

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: Yes.  Conviction.  Conviction that I'm onto the truth.  You're going to do the same thing to "poor bastard number four" that you did to the last three.  You're going to run again.  And I'm not leaving until you do.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: You're going to be very disappointed.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: We'll see.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: I'd love to stay and chat, but I've got to get back to work.  I still have my job.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: I have nothing to hide, Mr. Graham. Talk to whoever you want.  You might actually stumble upon a fact or two.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: Hey, kid, I'll give you ten bucks for your hat.

Speaker: walter
Dialogue: You know, when I only see one dog, I know I've had too much to drink.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: You'll never guess who came crawling into town with his tail between his legs.

Speaker: walter
Dialogue: In other words -- he's only human.  An he brought us a bottle of wine.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: They made me put my hat back on.

Speaker: walter
Dialogue: Oh, yeah.  Scared the hell out of Skipper.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: You've got to be kidding me.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: It wasn't that funny.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: So, the forces of good and evil have already met.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: I'll help you take into the kitchen.

Speaker: grandma julia
Dialogue: Check on the crabs, Bob.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: Gee, I hope they don't have a fight out there.  You don't think they'll call it off...?

Speaker: walter
Dialogue: Well, wedding cake freezes.  This we know.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: You know, your daughter seems...

Speaker: grandma julia
Dialogue: Sorry.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: That's okay, Grandma.

Speaker: walter
Dialogue: Like her mother.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: I just can't see her leaving multiple grooms in the dust like that.

Speaker: grandma julia
Dialogue: Oh, yes, you can.  She's has 'em all on tape.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: She has a tape?

Speaker: walter
Dialogue: Yeah.  Lee at the hotel videos wedding. I mean Maggie didn't know she was going to make the hundred-yard dash.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: Dad's fishing trip, Grandma's knee operation, Grandma's birthday...

Speaker: walter
Dialogue: Gotta tell you this about my daughter. My daughter makes real good time, even in a long dress and heels.  Maggie may not be Hale's longest running joke, but she certainly is the fastest.

Speaker: grandma julia
Dialogue: Ha ha.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: This is good, Dad, don't leave anything out.

Speaker: walter
Dialogue: So I've come to see it as a bonus, really, that we've been able to plan, and pay for, so many weddings.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Not this one.  This one's on me.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: That's fair.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Despite what you think, I don't do it on purpose.  And I have no intention of doing it again.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: That's right, Maggie.  Just keep your eye on the ball.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: Ahh.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: I'm the town's unofficial fitness trainer.  Big advocate of the mind and body combining for success.  You could say or you can quote me, I'm a glass half full king of guy.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Bob's the head of the P.E. department at the high school.  And he coaches the football team.  And he's climbed Everest.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: Everest.  Is that right?

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Twice...

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: Really?

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Without oxygen...

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: My girl likes to brag about me.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: How romantic.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: We think so.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: Nothing like sharing your nuptial bed with two Sherpas and a yak.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: You won't believe what I'm looking at, Fisher.  A videotape of all three train wrecks.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: Kamikaze!

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: Did you see that?

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: No, he's no good.  Too blond.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Too dark.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: But he's got the Bobster's eyes.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: Let's see... Excuse me, isn't that cute? Ahh...

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: Yes, I am.  And who are you?

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: Oh, Betty.  I take it you're going to be making the wedding cake and they say you're throwing --

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Grandma made me the cutest outfit.  I can't wait to show it to you.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: A pre-wedding luau?

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: Fun?  Fun isn't the word.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: No, I'm sure he doesn't.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: Thank you.  Thank you so much.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Is that what you're going to do now? Follow me around everywhere I go?

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: Bye, Betty.  Thanks.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: He's not a nice person.

Speaker: dennis
Dialogue: Maggie, don't marry Coach!  Marry me. I love you.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: You're jail bait, Dennis.  Go away. Run your laps.  Go. Go.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Drive!  Drive!  From your hips, get low, get low, get low.  Next!

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: What is he up to now?

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Ike just came by to check out the team.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: And talk about you.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Bob -- are you making friends with this man?

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: I'm just bragging about how great you are.  I'm the luckiest man alive.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: Well -- I've got to get moving -- lot of work to do today!  I'll see you two love-birds later.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: See you at the wedding.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: You bet ya, Coach.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: At the wedding?  You invite him?  Bob, don't you realize he's writing another article about me?

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Sure I do.  But the bet defense is a good offense, right?  You're not going to let your opponent throw you off your game.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: You don't understand this guy.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Let him come to the wedding.  You're not running, right?  Say it. "I'm not..."

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: I'm not running.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: So if you're not running and Ike Graham is there to see it, then any article he writes has got to have a happy ending, right?  All we're doing is turning lemon into lemonade.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: I've got news for you.  No amount of sugar and water is going to turn like Graham into something you want to take on a picnic.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Where's that homemade sunshine?

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Bless me, Father, for I have sinned. My last confession was... ahh...

Speaker: priest
Dialogue: Of an impure nature?

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: No -- like -- I'm having a problem with that whole turn-the-other-cheek concept. I want revenge.  I want to destroy this guy's life, career, everything. On the sin scale, how big is that?  I mean, can I "Hail Mary" my way out of it?

Speaker: priest
Dialogue: Child, any sin in one's heart is...

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: The name's Maggie.  It wasn't this side of ten years ago that you had your tongue down my throat.  So don't call me "child", Brian.  It annoys me.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Brian, open up.  Don't ignore me.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: You're not even Catholic, Maggie -- you really shouldn't come to confession.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: I'm sorry.  I'm just so stressed out about that slime-ball reporter being in town.  I jus had to come warn you he might show up here and start asking you all kinds of ridiculous questions.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Actually, he only asked me one ridiculous question.  The rest weren't so bad.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: What?  You talked to him!  Did you tell him we dated before you were a priest?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Yes, yes, I'm sure I only did you good, Maggie.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: What did he ask?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: No, no.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Only respectful things.  What did we have in common back then... What kind of music did you like... Did you ruin my life when you left me standing at the altar...

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: And what did you say?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: How could I be angry at you when clearly what has happened to me is as God intended?

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Good one!  Thanks.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: It happens to be how I feel.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: God... Of course.  I'm sorry -- I mean, I'm...  Brian -- I've got to go.  The man's a lunatic, but I know exactly where he's going next.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: God bless you, Maggie.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Oh, wait, my purse.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: He wanted to know how you used to like your eggs.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Weird.  Like after all those years you would remem--

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: -- Scrambled, with salt, pepper and dill.  Same as me.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: I'm really sorry that I hurt you, Brian.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: I'm happy here, where I'm supposed to be.  But if you ever become a Catholic, may I ask you a favor, Maggie?

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Could your confess to Father Patrick from now on?

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Gill?  Lydia?  Gill?

Speaker: gill
Dialogue: Hey -- I found it!

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Found what?

Speaker: gill
Dialogue: Mags!  Hey, look -- The tape from the Radio City Music Hall concert -- Remember that night I as trying to get Jerry to let me sit in on "Ripple"?

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: ... Don't show him that picture of me at the concert in San Francisco --

Speaker: gill
Dialogue: We went to San Francisco twice. Remember one time we had a flat tire... Which picture?

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: And I see there was a chill in the air.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Give me that!

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: But the most interesting thing here is that I don't see the rose tattoo that I've heard about on your back.

Speaker: gill
Dialogue: Ike bet me fifty bucks you don't still have it, Mags.  I said "You're on, man! Maggie loved that thing!"  And I could really use fifty bucks.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: I'm not gonna show you guys anything. I am a soon-to-be-married woman.  Now give me that photograph.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: Sure, I would love to give this to you. Just give us one quick gander at that rose, and, I'll gladly hand it over.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Fine.  Here.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: Completely.

Speaker: gill
Dialogue: Maggie?  You got it removed?

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: Gill, I'll go ya double or nothing if was a stick-on.

Speaker: gill
Dialogue: Maggie?

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: I'm really, really afraid of needles... It doesn't make me a bad person.

Speaker: gill
Dialogue: Look.

Speaker: ike
Dialogue: Look, look, man.  I think the man is heartbroken.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: He is not!

Speaker: gill
Dialogue: I think I am.
